articles.title: Tesla Aims to Produce First 'Legion' of Optimus Robots in 2025
articles.excerpt: CEO Elon Musk has announced that Tesla is targeting the start of production for its Optimus humanoid robot this year, with ambitions to deploy them in factories.
articles.author: Teslarati
articles.fullContent:
Tesla Targets 2025 for Initial Optimus Robot Production

Tesla is aiming to begin production of its Optimus humanoid robot in 2025, CEO Elon Musk announced during a recent company-wide meeting. The ambitious timeline signals Tesla's intent to become a leader in robotics and automation, with plans to initially deploy the robots within its own manufacturing facilities.

A 'Legion' of Robots

Musk stated that the goal is to produce the first 'legion' of Optimus units, suggesting a significant number of robots are planned for the initial production run. These robots are intended to perform repetitive and dangerous tasks currently handled by human workers, which could revolutionise factory efficiency and worker safety. The development of Optimus is seen as a key step towards a future where humanoid robots can assist with a wide range of tasks beyond manufacturing.

"The development of Optimus is arguably the most important product development we're doing." — Elon Musk

Future Outlook

While the 2025 production target is aggressive, it underscores the priority Tesla places on the Optimus programme. Successful deployment in Tesla's factories would serve as a real-world proof-of-concept, paving the way for broader applications in logistics, healthcare, and even domestic assistance. The company continues to showcase advancements in the robot's dexterity and learning capabilities through regular video updates.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Tesla aims to start production of its Optimus humanoid robot in 2025.
  • ✔ The initial robots are planned for deployment in Tesla's own factories to handle repetitive tasks.
  • ✔ CEO Elon Musk views the Optimus programme as one of the company's most critical development projects.
  • ✔ The long-term vision is for Optimus to be a versatile robot capable of performing a wide variety of tasks.

articles.title: Apple Upgrades Vision Pro with M5 Chip and Longer Battery Life
articles.excerpt: Apple has refreshed its Vision Pro mixed-reality headset with the new M5 processor, promising smoother performance, crisper visuals, and a 30-minute battery life improvement.
articles.author: Chris Velazco
articles.fullContent:
Apple's refreshed headset incorporates the new M5 chip for enhanced performance.

Vision Pro Receives M5 Chip and Battery Boost

Apple has unveiled an updated version of its $3,499 Vision Pro mixed-reality headset, now equipped with a new M5 processor and improved battery life. The refresh aims to boost performance amidst growing competition in the spatial computing market, with Apple claiming the new chip will make web browsing smoother and visuals appear crisper.

Performance and Display Enhancements

The M5 chip introduces significant performance upgrades, including a 10-core CPU and a 10-core GPU with hardware-accelerated ray tracing. This allows the Vision Pro to render 10% more pixels, resulting in sharper images and text. The headset's display can now support a refresh rate of up to 120Hz, an increase from the previous 100Hz, which is intended to reduce motion blur and create a smoother experience, particularly when using Mac Virtual Display.

AI-powered features are also expected to run up to 50% faster thanks to the M5's 16-core Neural Engine. Despite these internal upgrades, the price remains at $3,500, and the device's overall design and weight have not been reduced.

Battery and Accessories

The refreshed Vision Pro now offers up to 2.5 hours of general use and three hours of video playback, a 30-minute improvement over the original model. The device also comes with a new, more comfortable Dual Knit Band, which can be purchased separately by owners of the first-generation headset.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Apple has upgraded the Vision Pro with its new M5 chip for faster performance.
  • ✔ Battery life has been extended by 30 minutes, offering up to 3 hours of video playback.
  • ✔ The display now supports a 120Hz refresh rate for smoother visuals.
  • ✔ The price remains unchanged at $3,499, and the headset's weight has slightly increased.

articles.title: JWST Captures 'Exciting' New Details of M87 Black Hole Jet
articles.excerpt: The James Webb Space Telescope has revealed unprecedented details of the massive jet of subatomic particles shooting out from M87*, the first black hole ever to be directly imaged.
articles.author: Live Science
articles.fullContent:
A composite infrared image from JWST showing the jet erupting from M87*.

Webb Telescope Reveals Unseen Details in Famous Black Hole Jet

New images from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have provided the clearest infrared view ever of the gargantuan jet blasting from the supermassive black hole M87*. Located 54 million light-years from Earth, this is the same black hole that was the subject of the first-ever direct image captured by the Event Horizon Telescope in 2019.

A Clearer View of Cosmic Power

The jet of subatomic particles, which extends for thousands of light-years, is being catapulted through space at nearly the speed of light. Using its Near Infrared Camera (NIRCam), JWST has captured the jet's structure in unprecedented detail, also revealing the fainter counter-jet moving in the opposite direction for the first time in infrared light. Scientists isolated the jet's light from the surrounding galaxy to study its features across four infrared wavelengths.

A previous radio image from the Very Large Array shows the M87 jet is about 8,000 light-years long.

Near the black hole, the jet exhibits a helical, or spiral, shape with complex structures, confirming it shines via synchrotron radiation—light emitted by charged particles spiralling in magnetic fields. This detailed analysis allows scientists to better understand how particles are accelerated and how energy is transferred from the black hole into the jet.

"The M87 jet is special in the sense that it is fairly close by (on astronomical scales), and very bright across the spectrum. This makes it an ideal laboratory to study jet physics." — Jan Röder, Astrophysicist, Institute of Astrophysics of Andalusia

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ JWST has captured the most detailed infrared images yet of the jet from the M87* black hole.
  • ✔ The images reveal new structural details and the faint counter-jet for the first time in infrared.
  • ✔ The data confirms the jet shines through synchrotron radiation, providing insights into particle acceleration.
  • ✔ M87* was the first black hole to be directly imaged by the Event Horizon Telescope.

articles.title: Hidden 'Doomed' Star Revealed by JWST Solves Decades-Old Mystery
articles.excerpt: The James Webb Space Telescope has observed a massive red supergiant star just before it exploded, solving the mystery of why these stars are rarely seen before going supernova.
articles.author: Live Science
articles.fullContent:
The JWST observation shows the massive red supergiant (inside the box) just before it exploded.

JWST Finds Hidden Supergiant, Solving Supernova Mystery

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has captured a massive red supergiant star just moments before it exploded, solving a long-standing astrophysical mystery. For decades, astronomers have wondered why red supergiants, which theoretical models predict should be the cause of most supernovae, are so rarely observed before they detonate. The new findings suggest they are often hidden behind thick clouds of dust.

Piercing the Dusty Veil

The supernova, named SN 2025pht, was first detected in June 2025 in the galaxy NGC 1637, located 38-40 million light-years from Earth. A team led by astronomers from Northwestern University used JWST's powerful infrared capabilities to analyse images of the area taken before the explosion. By comparing these with archival Hubble data, they identified the progenitor star.

The star was incredibly bright—about 100,000 times more luminous than our sun—but was shrouded in so much dust that its visible light was dimmed by more than 100 times. This dust blocked shorter, blue wavelengths of light, making the star appear extremely red. JWST's ability to see in infrared allowed it to pierce through this dusty cocoon and observe the star directly, marking the first time a supernova progenitor has been identified at mid-infrared wavelengths.

"For multiple decades, we have been trying to determine exactly what the explosions of red supergiant stars look like. Only now, with JWST, do we finally have the quality of data and infrared observations that allow us to say precisely the exact type of red supergiant that exploded." — Charlie Kilpatrick, Research Assistant Professor, Northwestern University

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ JWST has directly observed a red supergiant star just before it went supernova.
  • ✔ The discovery solves the mystery of why these stars are rarely seen before exploding: they are hidden by thick dust clouds.
  • ✔ The star, progenitor of supernova SN 2025pht, was 100,000 times brighter than the sun but was heavily obscured.
  • ✔ This is the first time a supernova's source star has been identified using mid-infrared wavelengths.

articles.title: Star Citizen Alpha 4.4 to Launch Next Month With New Nyx System
articles.excerpt: Cloud Imperium Games has announced that Star Citizen's third explorable star system, Nyx, will be released in the Alpha 4.4 update next month.
articles.author: Wccftech
articles.fullContent:
The Nyx system will feature hazardous environments and distinctive cold lighting.

Star Citizen's Third Star System, Nyx, Arrives in Alpha 4.4

Cloud Imperium Games (CIG) announced during its CitizenCon Direct 2025 event that Nyx, the third explorable star system in Star Citizen, is set to launch next month with the Alpha 4.4 update. The new system will be accessible from the existing Stanton and Pyro systems and is characterised as a hazardous, asteroid-dense environment.

Exploring the Nyx System

The Nyx system is described as a lawless region, featuring the Glacian Belt, distinctive cold lighting, and nebulae. The main outpost, Levki, has been rebuilt as a fully explorable social and economic hub with improved interiors, new shops, a hospital, and a refinery. The planet Nyx itself has almost no atmosphere and is blasted with extreme heat and solar radiation, requiring players to use special gear for exploration.

Alpha 4.4 will also introduce new mission arcs, including major storylines like 'Pyro Burn' and 'Science Runner Muk'. These missions will feature non-linear structures, social choices, and the first appearance of alien Vanduul ships in the persistent universe, adding new combat challenges.

New Technology and Future Plans

CIG also showcased its new 'Genesis' procedural generation technology, which will be used to create more realistic and natural worlds based on physical data like geology and temperature. While the initial version of Nyx will launch with Alpha 4.4, the system will be expanded with more locations and content throughout 2026.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ Star Citizen's third star system, Nyx, will be released next month in the Alpha 4.4 update.
  • ✔ Nyx is a hazardous, lawless system featuring extreme environments and a rebuilt social hub, Levki.
  • ✔ The update will include new non-linear missions and the introduction of alien Vanduul ships.
  • ✔ New 'Genesis' planetary generation technology will be used for future content creation.

articles.title: 4,500-Year-Old Pyramid Mystery Solved by Evidence of Hydraulics
articles.excerpt: The enduring mystery of how ancient Egyptians built the pyramids may have been solved, with new research suggesting a sophisticated hydraulic-powered mechanism was used.
articles.author: Indy100
articles.fullContent:
The Step Pyramid of Djoser is believed to be the oldest of the seven monumental pyramids.

Hydraulic Mechanics May Solve Ancient Pyramid Construction Mystery

A 4,500-year-old mystery about how the ancient Egyptian pyramids were constructed may have finally been solved, with experts pointing to the use of hydraulic mechanics. A new study suggests that the Step Pyramid of Djoser, the oldest of Egypt's great pyramids, was built using a hydraulic-powered lift to manoeuvre the massive stone blocks.

Evidence of a Water-Powered System

Researchers concluded that the internal architecture of the Step Pyramid is consistent with a hydraulic elevation mechanism, a technology never before reported for that time period. The theory posits that water pressure was used to push the oversized stone blocks into place from the pyramid's interior in what the authors describe as a 'volcano fashion'. This system would have been fed by a sophisticated network of waterways.

Analysis of the landscape and nearby structures, such as the Gisr el-Mudir enclosure, suggests the existence of dams and a temporary lake that could have connected to a 'Dry Moat' around the pyramid complex. This moat would have been part of a unified hydraulic system that managed water quality and flow, providing the necessary power for construction.

"This work opens a new line of research: the use of hydraulic force to erect the massive structures built by Pharaohs. We have uncovered a possible explanation for how the pyramids were built involving hydraulic force." — Researchers, as stated in their paper

Implications of the Discovery

If proven correct, this research demonstrates that ancient Egyptians possessed a powerful understanding of advanced hydraulic systems far earlier than previously believed. While some experts remain unconvinced, citing the lack of direct archaeological evidence for such machinery, the theory provides a compelling new perspective on ancient engineering capabilities.

Key Takeaways

  • ✔ A new study suggests the Step Pyramid of Djoser was built using a hydraulic lift system.
  • ✔ The internal architecture is consistent with a mechanism powered by water pressure to move stone blocks.
  • ✔ Evidence points to a network of dams, a temporary lake, and a moat that formed a unified hydraulic system.
  • ✔ The discovery implies a much earlier and more advanced understanding of hydraulic engineering by ancient Egyptians.
